reviewText:
A board game that relies completely upon one's ability to simply admit defeat from the get-go. You will go into this game expecting a fairly innocuous and casual romp best enjoyed with friends, and leave it screaming like an animal, cursing your very existence along with anyone who has wronged you while playing. Expect nothing and remember that when you're in the lead, your demise is right around the corner.

After hours of playing this game online, I've adopted an almost zen stoicism; if I'm two tiles away from completing an objective, I know I'll roll a one and get warped to the other edge of the map. I'm a changed man. 100% Orange Juice has lead me to renounce all expectation and desire, and to assume the worst from every situation.

A fun, lighthearted board game for enjoyment with friends, 10/10.

reviewText:
Before I say anything, 10/10. If you have ever played and liked Mario Party, Fortune Street, Dokapon Kingdom, or any real or digital board game, this game should be given great consideration.

100% Orange Juice goes into the long tradition of combining characters from different series by making them all into a single card game most recently done on Steam with Card City Nights or a board game most similarly done like Fortune Street. This game decided to do both. What I really enjoy about this game is that it is basically the first of its kind on Steam. It combines many core elements from Dokapon Kingdom like combat and different stats, Fortune Street for “promotions” and board control, and Mario Party for stars and the 3 item max system (no minigames unfortunately).

The main objective of this game is to get 5 normas. Normas are objectives that you need to achieve by either collecting stars or killing enemies. Once the objective is met, you need to land on an enemy orange or pass your own that you can automatically stop at even if you overroll. Each Norma will give you an additional level up star, from a start of 1, and caps at 5 for the 5th norma is victory. Higher stars mean you can use more powerful cards to help secure victory.

A dice is rolled at the start of each turn. Like other games of its kind, you can also use applicable items at this time, which this game implements as cards. Each card, as mentioned earlier, does have a minimum level requirement, so overly strong cards will not come out till late game. Across the board are many spaces. Green draws a card, red fights an enemy, yellow gains stars based on roll after landing, blue drops stars based on roll after landing, purple warps to another purple, and the orange marker is each corresponding color’s base that can automatically stopped at to get a norma if it is your own or landed on for the same purpose if not your own and can be used to heal. There is also a grey space that does nothing :(.

The combat in this system is really reminiscent of Dokapon Kingdom. In this game you can choose to fight whenever you pass an enemy or have to fight when another player fights you or you land on a red space. Each player only gets to do one attack and one defend each encounter. You can use applicable cards before combat if you have any that apply. During combat, the main decider of things is how high you roll for an attack and what defensive stance you take. When defending you can either defend, which will reduce the attack into their roll minus your roll with a minimum of one, or you can evade, which will completely avoid the attack only if you roll higher than the opposing roll. There are also boss battles that sometimes occur on red spaces that drop a lot of stars. If you reach 0 hitpoints, you will have to roll a dice to revive. It requries a roll of 5 or higher and then goes does by one each turn you fail. You also lose half your stars upon death and these go to the oppoment if defeated by that person.

This game is a lot of fun and you should strongly consider it. The only complaint one may have is this game contains a lot of pulp. Hours upon hours of pulp"."
voteText: 279 of 317 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
100% Orange Juice is an interesting board game that relies heavily on luck, which can complement or negate a player’s skill. The game has a vast array of characters, all drawn from games made by the publisher, Fruitbat Factory, and the developer, Orange_Juice.

GameplayBefore you play the game, you must choose out cards which have a unique effect on the gameplay. Each player puts in 10 cards into a community deck, meaning that any cards put in have a chance of being used by any player (aside from the character’s special ability cards). Each character is balanced in some way so that it is not too powerful, having either raised or lowered stats, as well as a higher or lower hp based on their stats to help even the playing field. I always thought of this game as an anime Mario Party, except without the mini-games after each turn. At the end of the turns, there is a chance of a boss monster appearing, or a board effect (which are chosen before the game starts, or already stuck into effect in campaign), which can damage players, regenerate health, and various other things as well. Each tile has it’s own effect, which makes the game far more interesting, especially for players figuring the game out for the first time.
Visuals and AudioThe game is very pleasing to the eye, where everything is so lively and colorful. The darker levels have a unique charm that contrast quite nicely with bright colored characters and tiles. The soundtrack is different for each level and compliments that level nicely, making each level have its own unique touch.
MultiplayerMultiplayer is still alive and well even two years after release. From the games I joined, the community is relatively friendly and is still welcoming to new players that try to pick up the game. Some games within multiplayer can be shorter than others, but can range from around 45 minutes to well over an hour. This is where most people play, as it can be more enjoyable to chat and play with real players while you play than bots. The randomness makes it a big addiction for players, as you never know what will happen that round, nor how good your luck will be.
Verdict: 8/10

This game will show you your friend’s true nature, and will test not only your luck, but also your ability to think ahead as well as your patience. Thankfully this game doesn’t have an in-game voice chat, or everyone would hear you scream when you keep getting low numbers.

If you enjoyed this review, or found it helpful, please feel free to follow our curator here.

reviewText:
100 PURASENTO ORANJU JUSO! is a cute and fun virtual board game.

Gameplay is fun, and cute graphics definitely adds to enjoyment. Randomness plays a big role in who wins, but with proper character and card selection, you can generally tip the odds in your favor against AI (at least on normal difficulty, and except for the maps that are meant to be hard). 100% OJ also has online multiplayer with easy matchmaking, so if you don’t like playing against AI getting into a game with real people is quick and easy.

Fully recommend it if you like board games or just looking for a fun casual game to play!

reviewText:
100% Orange Juice is a goal focused board game, played with charters from other popular anime games which have been released recently.  The game has been on Steam since mid 2013 and has an estimated 150k owners.

The rules of the game to begin with seem very overwhelming, dice are being rolled, characters are moving and you have no idea what is going on. I played/read the tutorial and this does help a bit to teach you the rules; but you will get more benefit out of just playing a game and learning as you go.  Each board/stage has various different squares, monster squares, pick up a card from the deck, teleport, coins, drops, and home. You roll a single D6 to move around the board. You have to complete 5 goals to win the game. The first goal that everyone starts each game with, is collect 10 coins.After you have completed this goal you then get to choose your following goals, you can continue hunting for coins, or you can switch to try kill a certain amount of monsters or players. My personal preference was to go for killing players as also drop goal too, meaning I could swap between the two goals to keep them as easy to accomplish as possible.

The graphics are generic anime style; although I watch a grand zero amount of anime, the art style does appeal to me. The cute sprites and levels are really colourful and are pleasing on the eye.

I did struggle for the first few stages of the game with the difficulty; but this was probably because I was still learning the rules, but once you pass the second level you should be plain sailing, I would recommend you play the game on the highest speed setting as some stages can go on for upwards of 40+ turns.

I finished the single player campaign with one character in just under four hours. Most of the gameplay and content for this game is to be found in the multiplayer mode; sadly I didn't see the option for a local multiplayer but you can certainly connect with friends online to play a round.

I can happily recommend 100% Orange Juice; it will have a home in some people's libraries if they are a fan of board games, it is not a fast paced game so some people may not like it; but if you want an evening of sitting back in your chair rolling dice over a cute little board game, 100% Orange Juice will easily quench your thirst (I'm sorry for that horrible pun!)

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

http://store.steampowered.com/app/282800

reviewText:
100% OJ is one of the few legit board games (that have functioning multiplayer) on Steam. I have spent most of my time trying to beat the campaign (mostly getting roflstomped by CPU) and I am impressed by the assortment of cards and characters that the game provides. All the units have their unique qualities even though they are not all born equal.

At times, I was extremely frustrated due to the RNG nature of any game that involves rolling the dice. I also experienced even more frustration at how overpowered the final boss of the game is.

Despite this, I genuinely had a good time collecting all the cards and completing specific challenges offered by the game's given achievements. Some of them were quite hard, some were tedious, and some were gained just from pure luck. This is a game that you should try to enjoy with good friends (especially if you want some of the harder achievements).

5/5 I would gladly buy a 4-pack on top of copy I already own when this game goes on sale.

Edit 1: The DLC is quite affordable and brings a good amount of content to boot!

reviewText:
Under the guise of a cute girls murder simulator ruled by RNG, 100% OJ is actually a surprisingly deep piece of educational software that everyone should play. In fact, all you mums and dads out there should encourage your kids to do the same. At gunpoint if necessary.

Some people will tell you anything's possible if you just try hard enough, chase your dreams and never give up. More often than not, these are rich dipsh*ts who were born to wealthy parents and never knew a day's work in their life and have their heads so far up their arses whenever they break wind the gas gets stuck in their esophagus instead.

100% OJ proves them wrong. Oh so wrong. Sometimes, no matter how hard you try, no matter how much of your very being you put into something, no matter how much you pray to your deity of choice, you will roll a 1 when 2 or better would suffice. 100% teaches you about failure and how everyone around you is out to get you. You will suffer. You will cry. You will curse this world and everything in it. You will wish harm upon your fellow man. You will become a horrible person. But you will also learn to handle everything life will throw at your miserable existence. And maybe, just maybe, one day one of those rich muppets will cut you off in traffic in their expensive cars... and you will have a x16 Big Rocket in your hand.

Best 7€ I've ever spent.

PS: Don't buy this if you own a gun.

reviewText:
A very fun virtual board game that has a good mix of skill and chance.  A distinctive feature is that you choose your set of cards, but the cards are all added to the same common deck -- which means your choice of cards (many of which have effects that aren't even specific to the user) ought to be ones that can benefit yourself even if other people use them.

Additionally, this is the first doujin (i.e. Japanese indie) game that I've seen where the localizers have not just vastly improved the game's functionality before release (such as changing the original password-based multiplayer to a Steam lobby based multiplayer), but are continuing to work on major new features, and even rebalancing the game based on player feedback.  The active community also helps provide feedback and suggestions.

Come join us!

(Disclosure: I acquired this game as part of the Indie Royale Back to School 2 Bundle.)

reviewText:
I've been addicted to this game and have been playing it nonstop over the past few weeks. With that in mind, I was compelled to write a review for it.

100% Orange Juice is a board game with characters from a number of Orange_Juice's other games like Suguri, QP Shooting, and Flying Red Barrel. It's a luck-based dice-rolling mayhem that's as entertaining as it is frustrating.

Pros:
+ The art style is cute and makes for nice visuals, and there are some catchy tunes to go with it.
+ The characters have different attributes and hyper cards that make the game fun and unique.
+ The DLC/bonus characters have their own little niche yet do not make the game pay to win.
+ Playing online is quick and easy and doesn't have very many problems. Disconnects happen, but they're rare.

Cons:
- It's heavily RNG based. Everything runs on dice rolls - from collecting stars to attacking opponents - which means that very little skill is involved. This will be a turnoff for some, but it also makes for very entertaining matches.
- Some rolls are rigged. This only applies to Tomomo's rolls in the last part of the campaign (where she is more likely to get 5's and 6's), but it is still a pain. Getting through the last chapters of the campaign (and Tomomo Hell) takes a long time as it is hard to defend against Tomomo's attacks or stop her from winning.
- The game is hard to pick up. You'll probably want to read the guide first before actually playing as you're thrown into the game without being told what happens. This is a rather big flaw, but, if you're able to look past it, you can enjoy the game.

TL;DR 100% Orange Juice has some flaws, but it's still worth getting if you've been wanting to play a fun board game with friends. If you don't like RNG-based games, then... this game is not for you.

reviewText:
100% Orange JuiceShort Review Version


What is 100% Orange Juice? 100%  Orange juice is a board game, despite the name. Yes its weird but considering what else this company have been pumping out the name does not come out as a surprise. Anyways back to the review.

100% Orange Juice is a boardgame that decided dice are not being used enough and that RNG is fun therefor it has decided to combine those two in an unholy union. What this means is in the game you can go from no.1 with only 10 more stars needed and 1 block away from home only to have your game character get teleported to somewhere else to the map most likely right in front of your opponent eager to destroy you. Or that you activated the booster card so you can roll 2 dice at once only for the dice to be 1 1 respectively.

Since this is a boardgame lets go with the gameplay first.

Gameplay~If there is a word for this game it is fun. On the chaotic scale. Here is the breakdown:

Choose Map>Choose Character>Choose Card>Play>Win/Lose>Get Stars/Level Up>Buy Stuff>Repeat

You can choose from a lot of map each with different pattern and different booster locations, once you choose your map you can then play it without modifier for a vanilla but boring experience or turn on a maximum of 3 modifier each with their own unique effect such as teleport, random damage, and even landmine the map.

Now onto the choose character screen. Now one thing I must mention is that there are a lot of character each with different stats but you start the game off with only a few with the rest requiring you to clear their story mode. Its not hard but does take some time. Once you choose your character you pick 10 different cards with different effects that will be shuffled into a deck along with all other player card choices then you are thrown into the map for gameplay with turn order being randomly decided.

As for the play itself it is rather simple. You collect a required amount of star or beat up a require number of people then roll dice to get back home to level up. Repeat 5 time with increasing number of star/defeated foe and you win the game but it is not that simple since other player also wants to win the game and the RNG cannot be appease.

Which is to say that you will most likely land on a trap card, get defeated by your opponent who have buffed themselves only 1 tile away from your home, landed on a suddenly appearing boss tile that will most definitely defeat you, or the classic old case of you losing to a chicken opponent after having landed on a encounter tile.

When you stumble on a opponent you can choose to end your turn and fight them along with whatever tile they are currently standing on. The way battles are decided is that if any player have buff/debuff card you play that first then the attacker proceed to get first turn at attack by rolling a dice. The defender can then choose to reduce the damage by rolling defence or try to completely negate the damage by evading but failure will make them suffer the full damage without reduction. The character stats modifies the final roll. Once a player is KO or both player have attack the battle is dismiss. If you KO the enemy plus you get half of their total coin amount and if you get KO you must diceroll a number that either matches or exceed the one display or screen with failure to revive cause you to lose a turn but the required diceroll for revive will be reduce by 1. Do note battle can be use tactically such as battling the opponent at their home base so you will stop and level up there but if you happen to challenge them while they are on a boss tile the good luck my friend.

This continues with player using cards, hyper cards that are unique to each character with profound effects, laying traps, and beating/collecting star until you reach star level 6 which will make you the winner of the match.

Once the match is over the total points are calculated and exp/star are given to every player with exp unlocking stuff at the shop and star used to purchase stuff [cards, character, hair colour] at the shops. Then you can either repeat again or find another lobby to play in.

Overall the experience is very enjoyable with the match being rather fast paced and minimum interaction needed but if you play with friends like what I did you can have an even more enjoyable time trash talking each other and generally doing stuff friends would do. The randomness of every match means that the game gets bored rather slowly but with more boards and character DLC that were release it does shake up the overall game a little bit more.

Also despite being a multiplayer focus game it does have bots so you don't have to worry about empty lobbies since you can just invite 1 friend and start immediately. They can be a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ though.

Option Menu & ControlsOrange Juice custome engine support a rather bare bone option menu.
It has the bare essential of resolution support, sound control, fullscreen option and a few other minor things.
No disability option here sadly. And yes it runs at 60 fps in case you ever needed this info.

The game plays entirely using the mouse with the keyboard only use if you ever want to chat. So its 1 handed friendly and with the sound cue that plays when its your turn you can minimize the game and do a little work while you wait your turn. Not recommended though.

SoundEach character has their own theme song that plays whenever you level up and they are pretty good while the overall sound direction itself has neither pro nor con. You can always mute it and play your own song if you want.

GraphicsIts 2D animate sprite that bounces with a bare minimal animated background. What you see is what you get.

ConclusionA fun little boardgame that does well with its focus on RNG being the factor on everything. Good game length and fun with friends plus it really has a solid gameplay means you can pick and play it with friends at your leisure. In fact I actually manage to clock 23 hours into this game without realizing it and that is value enough for me.

Scoring Methology:
-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

Verdict: A-Rank - A very good boardgame.

Credit:Thanks to meatking and smmoke for your help!

reviewText:
This is a great party game that is fast paced, simple to learn, while still being modestly split between RNG dice rolls and strategy. The game's assets are not triple A material by any means, but is well polished and works great. The characters, cards, maps, bgm, sound effects, etc are all endearing and very enjoyable.

I had so much fun playing this game. So so so much fun. But now all my friends are dead, or have left me in disgust. This game does terrible things to people. At first, the malice that takes root in your heart is nothing but the result of a natural competitive drive. It grows within you, and as the finish line approaches, it whispers at you words of betrayal, sabotage, and subversion. We've all felt it before, using ghosts to steal stars in a certain party game, or using blood drenched shells to topple your friends in a kart racing game... but it is nothing compared to the devilish desire for victory that 100% Orange Juice instills upon your fragile mind.

You would see your former comrades burn and wither away, just for the sake of attain glorious norma. They will cry in agony, beg and pray, to cease your ascension to the 6th level of corruption BUT NAY, YOU HEED NO WORDS OF THE PLEBEIANS WHO DARED CHALLENGE YOU AT 100% ORANGE JUICE, THEIR LAST ATTEMPTS AT APPEALING TO YOUR SENSE OF PITY LANDS NAUGHT ON YOU NOR THE RNG GODS, FOR YOU ARE A WINNER, BAKSING IN THOSE RAINBOW LETTERS, YOU CELEBRATE UPON THE CORPSES YOU'VE TRAMPLED UPON.

But only once the euphoric high wears off and your adrenaline clears... only then do you realize your mistakes. The carnage left behind. This game. It will leave your friends list empty. I have to start over from scratch now, as if I were a trasnfer student at an oriental high school. And never, will I ever recommend playing 100% Orange Juice with them.

reviewText:
100% RNGjuice is a great game, a load of fun, and its not 100% RNGjuice because there is about 30% player choice involved too. Still fun to play with friends or meet new friends. to explain what this game is further, its a battle board game with rolls being everything, each character has 4 stats; Health Attack Defense and Dodge, and all of these have their own place and nobody (except a ban-able character) feels over powered. Game is a solid card gathering, friend battling, board game.


So now the standard game rating:Story: 10/10 (Each player has a story, and for a mash-up game like this is I'm quite surprised that they managed to make this happen. All the characters are enjoyable.)
Gameplay: 10/10 (you can't beat the RNG gods in this but its still a hell of a lot of fun.)
Presentation: 10/10 (2D Anime > 3D Anime Forever, all the other aesthetics are fitting as well as adorable.)
Soundtrack: 8/10 (Gotta admit I turned off the soundtrack after a while and just played my own. the music changes after each person gains a level so it keeps itself semi- not annoying. but still after hearing them for about 10 hours its not enjoyable to listen to anymore.)
Replayability: 10/10 (Play it with friends, beat the stories of all players, unlock everything, there is a load of things to do in this game.)

Sometimes, when I'm home by myself, I arrange a board game made of foam mats out on my floor....except all of the tiles are yellow. Every step I take. Every time my toes meet that soft, sun-kissed tile. Pure bliss. Pure Bonusu.\n

reviewText:
├Honest Review┤Review is based on current state of game.

Game Pros
• Play with up to 3 other friends
• Every character has unique combat attributes
• Over 50+ card to collect
•  4 Campaigns each with 5 stages and boss battles
• Overwhelming feel of achomplisment when you finally win
• Can become very strategic on how and when you play your cards
• Decent visuals
• Very entertaining and keeps your attention (For people who are into these types of games)
• Various enimies/bosses
• Great soundtrack
• Ability to choose between set goals (Gathering stars or killing enimies) that further your progression towards winning



Game Cons
• Non-existent tutorial in-game
• Dice rolls are random. So you play upon luck
• The Campaign makes you wanna smash your screen. It feels like the AI is using hacks even on the lowest difficulty. It's even worse when you get destroyed by a seagull
• To unlock advanced abilities and characters you have to grind forever


Relateable Games
• N/A

Conclusion100% Orange is a fun...board-game? Featuring cards that can really change the out come of the game depending on how you play them. Fight your friends, Bosses, Monsters, and Seagulls. Cause havoc with game changing cards, and use your winning to buy more card packs. If you have the money, i'd honestly give this game a chance. At least go check out some game-play. It can be very relazing, and highly frusterating at the same time.

(If you found this review helpful, consider giving it a thumbs up!)

reviewText:
A very fun game, specially for multiplayer, with a very friendly community.

It takes a Mario Party-esque formula and replaces the minigames with a card and a combat system. Players will be laying trap cards, using combat cards and changing the flow of the game in order to grab stars or defeat other players and monsters,

Each characters has his own unique attributes (HP, attack, defense and evade) and a unique Hyper! card, favoring some specific playstyle. Players will build their decks that will get mixed, meaning a player can get a card from any other player's deck.

Campaign mode features a very silly story with charismatic and cute characters.

However, it is a very luck based game, and, at least on campaign mode, the AI will cheat on the dice rolls. Be prepared to lose from advantageous situations due to sheer bad luck and AI cheapness.

Still, this doesn't stop 100% Orange Juice from being a very fun game to play!

reviewText:
This is a board game. Don't go in expecting anything else. Consquently, the game is mostly centered around luck (with a small amount of skill involved) and the single-player is, at its best, an overly long tutorial on why you should hate Poppo. Before you purchase, make sure you understand all of this.

With that disclaimer out of the way, I would like to say that this is one of the best-designed games released in the last couple years.  If you can find a few friends to play with, or look into the (reasonably active!) community, you'll find quite a bit to love in this game. The mechanics are everything that they need to be, the soundtrack is top-notch where it matters (unless you main Marc or Poppo), and if you're trying to experience everything the game has to offer, you'll actually be here for quite a while.

The gameplay, while leaving you constantly at the mercy of the RNG, is just as likely to screw over anyone else. In single-player, that can get tiresome, but once you've started playing multiplayer, that's all part of the fun. Life is short and so are individual games. You might lose one round to a crappy defend role, and you might win the next because of a lucky six. With the overall speed at which a game can be completed, it's all part of the fun. You're rewarded almost equally regardless of whether you win or lose, so don't get too caught up with all of that - just relax and let the dice craft wonderful webs of agony while you and your friends suffer in succession. All in all, it's one of the few multiplayer games I can consistently say that I have fun playing. And since this is a game, that's the important thing, isn't it?

That might not sell the game to you. It should, but it might not. And if it doesn't, then I'd like you to take a look at the update history for a moment. For this obscure $7 board game with a cast that's virtually unknown in the west, Fruitbat Factory has done the most stellar job of supporting a game post-release that I've ever seen. Not only have they added characters and maps to a small-name game released in 2009, but they actively look at user feedback and have introduced countless new features by popular demand, such as in-game chat and online avatars. In an era where publishers are eager to throw crap out the door at the first opportunity, I'm simply astounded at the work they've put into perfecting this little boardgame - for over a year and counting, now.

I have to wonder how Orange Juice feels. Perhaps they're amused at how their shooting-game characters are possibly best-known in the west as characters from a board game? Maybe so. They should be very pleased with themselves, though - they, along with the publisher that they've partnered with, have become one of the most brilliant examples of what the game industry could be in an ideal world. Rather than looking for new ways to milk their audience, they've been constantly at work improving this game from a simple tribute project to what is probably my favorite game that I played last year, and it's only getting better from here as they find more and more ways to add to the game.

Well, that's my two cents. Do you want an interesting and entertaining (but largely stress-free) multiplayer experience? Do you want to watch anime girls, shirtless men, and seagulls beat the daylights out of each other? Do you want to be a part of one of the best developer-user communities I've seen in a long time? If you answered yes to any of those questions, why not make like Yuki and make a gamble? We're always looking for new people to play!

hoursPlayed: and either attack other players
voteText: or interact with the tile they landed on. The main goal is to complete "normas" to level up (which gives you more stars per turn
helpfulPercent: as well as the ability to use stronger cards) via either stars or combat wins

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by the cute visuals. This board game is brutal, extremely addictive and a lot of fun! It mixes gameplay elements from Ludo, Monopoly and Risk into an unique game that is perfect to play with friends and even against the AI.

You can play on casual difficulty, normal difficulty or hard difficulty (on the later, the dice is loaded). A lot of reviews says that 100% Orange Juice is a game of luck only. I beg to differ. While the RNG is crucial here, you have great chances to win by skill, always choosing the best path on the board, the best moment to use a card and playing with a character that fits your style (aggressive or not).

100% OJ also has different types of board, campaigns and unlockables. The replay value is very high.

If you love board games, you can't miss this one.
Totally worth your money and time!

reviewText: Essentially, 100% Orange Juice is a turn-based board game with RPG elements and a Kawaii feel to it. You go around a board, roll dice, collect cards, and beat up monsters or other players/AI. The AI cheats a good bit and there is a reasonable sized campaign mode because of that and the time it can take to potentially beat just one campaign. Over-all, the game is good, but the bots are ridiculously unbalanced sometimes & it can kind of ruin the game. Lots of card decks you can build around your particular play-style making for a unique game-play each time especially online. It's a great novelty game and well worth the cost even not on sale. I wish there was a bit more unique strages, but for the $0.50 I ended up paying for it, i'm not complaining. Enjoyed every minute of it and plan on playing for many more hours to come. Be warned online when joining with too high of a level people, they tend to use some pretty OP cards so make sure your deck can handle a wide variety of strategies! Turbo mode is included for the campaign modes making games go by quickly and it's a great casual game you can leave open and do other stuff in while waiting for your next turn when it comes to online play.\n\nTLDR:Asian Mario Party, complete with turbo mode & cards dealing various status elements. It was mathematically a good investment as I got pretty much all my money back on cards for what I paid for it. I R mean no offense, but it was the easiest way for me to explain this game. It's a lot of fun! It's intense, and has weird voices that are fitting of these types of games :P

reviewText: This game is very addictive, cute, frustrating and fun all at the same time. A game where your luck comes from the roll of the dice with a little stratergy thrown in. You play as one of a few characters (which are based on level/experience) and inbetween each round you get a little story before the main event. You begin by clicking the left mouse button which rolls an ai dice and you can move as many paces, occasionaly picking which way to turn and continue your run. The goal? One of two choices, either collect stars or defeat monsters and other characters. The fighting is decided by the same click of the mouse and can be boosted by cards (if you have any) that have been picked up around the level.Each goal must be handed in at a spawning point but with members using trap cards, monsters including bosses, transporting squares and those that make you drop stars you can be assured that this game is not as easy as it sounds.\n\nYou can also buy items to help your game play (such as booster cards) and the more you advance in level you are the more you can buy. When I say buy I mean via stars you have collected, not with real currency like some other games do. For such a cheap price this is a great game and it offers great entertainment value. I know I will be suggesting it next time my brothers in law come to town. :)

reviewText: 100% Orange Juice is, at its essence, a simple board game. While it may take a game or two to fully grasp everything, it’s fairly simple, but also fairly brutal. Four players are placed on a board and must roll a die or dice to move forward either playing passively, trying to quietly and quickly obtain as many stars as you can, or aggressively, out for blood and attacking enemy spaces and opponents around every corner. The way the game challenges you to choose and alternate these styles of gameplay is what makes 100% Orange Juice an excellent game, as the player must be apprehensive in the face of the unfortunate circumstance where your strategy, and the world itself, has seemingly failed you.Different play styles offer a nice variety to how you approach your imminent destruction. I say imminent destruction because this game is hard as all hell. One big drawback is the intensity the computer AI is set to by default. With some other settings, the average player can ease into the game much more easily. As a result of its default difficulty, 100% Orange Juice can be soul-crushing.Gameplay aside though, 100% Orange Juice has a very nice and clean presentation. Considering all the lunacy going about, its effects are fairly minimal, and it’s probably better that way. 100% Orange Juice is far from perfect, but it’s still an exceptional virtual board game that really pushes your buttons. With some tweaks to the formula, specifically changeable difficulties, more consistent stage design, and some tweaks to the general presentation to help make the on-screen madness a bit more legible, 100% Orange Juice could really pick up speed with a phenomenal little series of board game titles. All the elements are there: charm, strategy, and madness.

reviewText:
Sometimes, video games can attract attention just because of their names. This is likely the case with 100% Orange Juice, even if the primarily response is confusion. After all, it sounds more like the description of a drink than any game! But 100% Orange Juice is very much a game and quite the fun one at that. You’ll just have to spend a bit of time learning about its rules to truly enjoy it.

The name of the game is 100% Orange Juice. Why? I don’t care, and I don’t think the game does either. The strange name is only the beginning, however, of the bizarre realm of 100% Orange Juice. Because I can’t pass up the opportunity to make a citrus joke here, the game is definitely sweet, but at times can appear very sour. In fact, I am pretty sure this game hates me.

100% Orange Juice is, at its essence, a simple board game. While it may take a game or two to fully grasp everything, it’s fairly simple, but also fairly brutal. Four players are placed on a board and must roll a die or dice to move forward either playing passively, trying to quietly and quickly obtain as many stars as you can, or aggressively, out for blood and attacking enemy spaces and opponents around every corner. The way the game challenges you to choose and alternate these styles of gameplay is what makes 100% Orange Juice an excellent game, as the player must be apprehensive in the face of the unfortunate circumstance where your strategy, and the world itself, has seemingly failed you.

100% Orange Juice is far from perfect, but it’s still an exceptional virtual board game that really pushes your buttons. With some tweaks to the formula, specifically changeable difficulties, more consistent stage design, and some tweaks to the general presentation to help make the on-screen madness a bit more legible, 100% Orange Juice could really pick up speed with a phenomenal little series of board game titles. All the elements are there: charm, strategy, and madness.

Because I can’t pass up the opportunity to make a citrus joke here, the game is definitely sweet, but at times can appear very sour. In fact, I am pretty sure this game hates me.

100% Orange Juice is, at its essence, a simple board game. While it may take a game or two to fully grasp everything, it’s fairly simple, but also fairly brutal. Four players are placed on a board and must roll a die or dice to move forward either playing passively, trying to quietly and quickly obtain as many stars as you can, or aggressively, out for blood and attacking enemy spaces and opponents around every corner. The way the game challenges you to choose and alternate these styles of gameplay is what makes 100% Orange Juice an excellent game, as the player must be apprehensive in the face of the unfortunate circumstance where your strategy, and the world itself, has seemingly failed you.

100% Orange Juice is far from perfect, but it’s still an exceptional virtual board game that really pushes your buttons. With some tweaks to the formula, specifically changeable difficulties, more consistent stage design, and some tweaks to the general presentation to help make the on-screen madness a bit more legible, 100% Orange Juice could really pick up speed with a phenomenal little series of board game titles. All the elements are there: charm, strategy, and madness.

reviewText:
Do you like strategy? Do you like watching your strategy absolutely dissolve in the face of a RNG that exists only to screw you over?

This is the game for you. It's basically Mario Party without the minigames and with even more frustration.

With a campaign mode and a free-play mode, there are plenty of ways to increase your blood pressure tenfold. The campaign loosely follows little stories of each of the characters who are all pretty endearing. The difficulty increases a bit each time with the people you face, culminating in a boss that leaves you crying on the floor and screaming into a pillow.

There are numerous characters you can play as, each with different stats and their own advantages and disadvantages. These stats help a bit to make the RNG more in your favor when it comes to battles by increasing or decreasing your rolls. The stats can be augmented before battle with cards as well, adding some strategy to it all.

All in all, this game is definitely worth it. You will probably get angry and lose friends if you play with them, but that's just a part of life. You'll get over it, eventually.

reviewText: Actually a great game. Reviews convinced me 100% OJ was worth the buck or so I paid in the last sale. Usually when I buy random games, I don't read up on them too much, just to be surprised, so I was indeed surprised to find it was a cutesy board game with more RNG than *insert Hearthstone bash here*. It reminds me of the old Mario Party games - you can be winning by a mile all game, but someone might still steal all your stars at the last moment and you'll take last place. If you play with friends, it's nonstop laughter at each other's expense. My experiences with the online community have been fantastic as well, very friendly banter and responses all game long. There is a story mode, and it's about a little girl's quest for her lost pudding, so that right there tells you OJ doesn't take itself seriously. One of my favorite experiences on Steam :)

reviewText:
A Mario Party Monopoly Love Child, With RNG Mixed In To Make A Beautifully Evil Baby
tl;dr: If you are a fan of Orange_Juice, a very casual and mellow player, a fan of anime and/or cutesy graphics, ok with RNG games or are a masochist, this game is for you. If not, you may not want to buy it... Maybe. Try it if you can.

100% Orange Juice is the 5 year anniversary game of Japanese Indie game developer Orange_Juice, starring some of their hit characters from Suguri, Sora, QP Shooting, and Flying Red Barrel - Diary of a Little Aviator. Now, you might be asking WHAT THE HELL ARE THESE GAMES!?" and to that I answer that they're Indie and Japanese
date: and you need to know nothing about the characters to enjoy this game. If anything
recommended:
this game is the gateway game to try out the rest of Orage_Juice's catalogue here on Steam!

General Overview
Before each game
hoursPlayed: you can choose a character and what cards you want in the deck each game. At the start of each game
voteText: everyone starts at their own home
helpfulPercent: with a single star and card. You play by completing Norma
votesHelpful: which are objectives. Each game starts with every player needing to collect 10 stars
votesTotal: but you can choose to change it after you get 10 stars. You can choose to collect stars or battle for wins to achieve the set Norma. Once you collect the number of stars or wins
votesFunny: you must land on a home
commentsCount: which you can stop at whenever you pass it
column16: or land on someone else's home in order to achieve the Norma. The first player to complete 5 Norma wins. In addition
column17: the cards you choose can be randomly drawn out the deck at certain times

column19: though for the sake of time

column27:
it's quick and easy to learn it all.

Pros

- Great music
column29: windy music to techno dance beats\n- A very alive and well multiplayer community in which almost everyone is a nice person\n- A board
column31: and turn based combat hybrid game that somehow blends perfectly\n- Never the same gameplay. There will be constants
column32:
but the RNG makes it so that anything can happen at any moment.
- A singleplayer campaign that's pretty fun

column34:
and Super Meat Boy

you can invoke that)

Cons

column38: which means that you can add strategy

but it's mostly up to luck.

so you'll have to rely on someone joining your game or you finding a public game

and even then it kinda sucks

Conclusion
It's like a Mario Party and Monopoly hybrid

reviewText:
I got this game from a good friend who thought, since it is full of anime cuteness, that it would be my cup of tea---or orange juice, LOL SO FUNNY!!!!twelve

Seriously, the game is very very VERY cute! The characters and sounds and the colors are all sugary sweet and adorable. The gameplay, on the other hand, will take a bite out of you! It's hard! Not hard in a bad way, just hard in that the computer characters will do everything they can to beat the living tar out of you AND everything is pretty much based on a roll of the dice. You can use cards to help you out, and buy upgrades from an in-game shop with the stars you earn while playing Campaign mode or Free mode.

And then, there is the Lobby online mode thing!! I have never had such fun conversing with all sorts of people--many of them new friends!! I'm so glad they added the Chat option to the online games, it makes watching dice flying around, beating up small birds and getting your butt kicked by a demon spawn or a bunny ♥♥♥♥♥ (Poppo and Tomomo) FUN!!

Okay, it makes it MORE fun! Give it a try, and who knows, we might end up playing a game together :D!

reviewText: In the vast world of anime, snake eyes are the last thing you wish to see. But in this vast world of Orange Juice, you must get accustomed to the sight. There will be bonusus. There will be duroppus. Though they appear overwhelmingly moe, the people of this world are more than willing to betray you with dice loaded to the brim with kawaii. And as you walk away victoriously, a single thought will slip through one of the many insignificant cracks in your head, into your slowly kawaiitizing mind. A thought that inspires faint hope, but comes dowsed in a pot of trepidation and dread. Bravely you will proceed to the answer to this very notion.\n\nMaybe... maybe now there is hope... maybe now, Senpai will notice me!

reviewText:
50% Collectable Card Game + 50% Board Game = 100% Orange Juice

Just completed my first free play (3rd place :\) and felt compelled enough to write a review already. Already liked War of the Human Tanks (pubilshed? also by Fruitbat Factory), so maybe just a bit biased there.

Gameplay: Feels like Mario Party with cards mixed in; I like it.

Music: From the main menu screen to the idle music while reading instructions on how to play, to the actual gameplay, music is great :D


Just watch out for that RNG: you get the card-drawing RNG combined with the dice-rolling RNG, and that can be a killer.

reviewText:
This game already has tons of positive reviews and hardly needs mine to be shown as a success. But I've sunk over 400 hours into it and I'm sure many, many more will come in the future. As such, I feel obligated to give another thumbs up here. Plus, I just want to talk about how much I enjoy it.

100% Orange Juice is a mash-up of several Orange Juice game characters in a board game setting, along with a couple of made-for-this-game ones. Before playing this, I only knew of Sora, and only because I had heard the soundtrack from her game. So this is coming from someone who was totally exposed to Orange Juice games because of this one.

You can get this for single player use. Campaign modes exist, five in all, and if I were to get the game just to play those, I would consider it a worthwhile purchase. That being said, campaign mode severely suffers for one major reason: the AI cheats. I don't mean that in an I get so unlucky that it feels like they're always doing well" way. The game's code has shown that difficulty levels going up causes it to be more likely that the AI will get the rolls they need. This is artificial difficulty at its finest
date: and if that was not a part of this game
recommended: I would have nothing else to complain about.\n\nHowever
hoursPlayed: multiplayer is where 100% Orange Juice shines. There the luck is truly random (no matter how you might feel otherwise)
voteText: both for players and any AI you have filling in the slots. Lag is almost nonexistant from my experiences
helpfulPercent: and it is very easy to link up with friends to play. There is a lot of hilarity to be had
votesHelpful: and I have gotten so many hours put into this game simply because it is so much fun with other players.\n\nThere are a variety of boards
votesTotal: almost all of which are fun for different reasons (I loathe Farm
votesFunny: but that's the only exception for me). The cards used in the game are of a good variety

reviewText: 100% Orange Juice is a great game to just kick back and have some fun with friends.  The game can be a bit confusing at first, and while there are guides you can read, I highly recommend just jumping into a game and talking to people.  The community is awesome, so don't be afraid to ask questions!  When I first started playing, I had no idea what was going on, but then I met some amazing people that really helped me out big time, explaining some strategies and how different cards work.  There are a couple bad apples here and there, but by and large, the community in 100% Orange Juice is very friendly, likes to joke around, have fun, and commiserate when we roll a 1 at the worst possible time or teleport away from home right when we thought we were going to win the game.\n\nBasically, the goal is to accumulate as many stars or wins as you can during the game.  Each time you step on a home with enough stars or wins, you will gain another norma
date:
which lets you use more powerful cards.  There is definitely some strategy involved depending on the character you choose.  Try to pick cards that suit your character's strengths and avoid cards that don't.  A little basic knowledge of probability helps but isn't required.  Also,  pray to the Orange Juice gods and goddesses.  Luck is a huge element of this game, so you will want divine intervention on your side!

Campaign mode can be a little frustrating if you don't know what you're doing, which is why I recommend getting some tips from other players first, but it's also required to unlock most of the non-DLC characters.  This is one of my only real complaints about the game.  It can be kind of unclear how to unlock the characters you want.  When I was starting out, it felt like it took forever to get my favorite characters that I saw my friends using in multiplayer.  If you stick with it through campaign mode, they'll all eventually become available in the store though.

That said, the nice thing about campaign mode is that the story is *incredibly adorable.*  The dialogue in all of the campaigns puts a smile on my face every time, and the characters have very expressive animations.  Personally, I recommend Marc and QP's campaigns for maximum cuteness, but all 4 have nice stories.  Red Barrel all the way!

Most importantly, don't sweat the small stuff.  For every bad roll you get, eventually you'll get an amazing roll to put the smile back on your face.  Meet new people, relax, and have fun.

reviewText:
When I 1st played 100% Orange Juice I was skeptical about it because of its colorful content but this game surprised me with its addictive gameplay (Think of Mario Party & DARK SOULS combined together with cards as the secret ingredient), the game devs are committed to updating the game & listening to feedback (Very friendly too), The character's theme songs are very catchy, The game has multiplayer (Everyone is committed to discuss a day to play together in the steam group chat or what parts of the game need to be buffed, removed or nerfed), The cards to me are a 50/50 chance of helping you win or to help you fail (Try them all out) & if your into colors or cuteness then this game is definitely for you (I'm personally into disgusting/dark content in videogames but this game was very enjoyable & worth playing 40+ hours on).

The only negative that grinds my gears is the recent update that changed the dice animation to make it permanently slow (I spent my entire time playing the game on the fastest game speed & now it's slow as hell so I hope the devs change the speed back because that is a major turnoff). Overall I really suggest buying this game & if your still not convinced then watch this vid.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gw49jIghgW0

UPDATE: The Devs released 4 new characters which you can buy here http://store.steampowered.com/app/327340/

http://store.steampowered.com/app/334080/

reviewText:
Loads of cute anime fun with one of its biggest positives being that it's very simple to learn once you have a go at it.
It can be rage inducing at times with its occassionally harsh NPC AI, but it's highly enjoyable when playing with other people. This is definitely a kind of game I'd rather play with friends as opposed to the CPU.

It isn't a perfect game and there are things that could be improved upon in the future, but these things don't detract from the overall fun you'll probably have.
I don't regret buying it, I've had a load of enjoyment for a small price.

Hoping for more updates in the future!

reviewText:
Positives:
- Great fun game which is very cute!
- Will be loved by anime and non-anime fans
- Centers around boardgame style gameplay, battles are involved
- Offers a variety of characters
- Campaign mode is available
- Offers Casual, Normal and Hard Difficulty
- Vibrant community to socialise and play with per multiplayer function

Neutral:
- Operates via RNG (random number generator)
- Unlockable Boss characters are nerfed, I wanted to class this as a negative but we must remember games of this nature require balance within character stats. It will be unfair to have an over powered character in multiplayer which will destroy all newbies which arrive, this will put newbies off from the game as they will have a difficult time winning and leveling up.

Result: 10/10 for a BOARD GAME styled game.

reviewText:
Do you like Orange Juice?
Do you like Mario Party/Dokapon Kingdom/actual board games?
Do you like dice oriented combat?
Do you like setting or activating trap cards?
Do you like raging about RNG shenanigans?
Do you like online multiplayer?

If you said yes to at least two of these things, you'll probably be interested in this game.

I should probably also note I've cleared the entirety of the campaign and filled out the card album, both of which are probably going to be really annoying for a lot people to do, but well worth it in order to maximize enjoyment of the game by unlocking stages/characters and getting the right cards for an interesting game. Oh, and the online multiplayer is a blast if you can get together a group that won't ragequit over this game's wacky hijinks.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Ugh.                                                  AESTHETIC: Lazy
MEMORABILITY: Cute                                   WORTH: Light Discount

PROS: Lots of board options. Engaging gameplay, and a campaign mode. Plenty of unlockables. Most people on my friend list have it back from when it had a wildly-popular stint, meaning there is no shortage of players I know. There also appears to be plenty of online matches whenever I get on.

CONS: The sounds are repeated ad nauseum, and the graphics are infuriating. I'd offer my own graphics for free if it meant seeing tokens that are a little more lively. I get that they're supposed to be board pieces, but the way they've gone about it looks really bad. There are also plenty of people playing it, but they all appear to be hardcore players of this game, making their play-style much faster and impatient for yours.

OVERALL:  I don't know why people keep calling this a steam Mario Party
date: it has virtually nothing in common with that series. However, it IS one of the only online multiplayer board games available right now, so it's filling a niche and it's doing it well.\n\nSCORE: 7/10

reviewText: This is truly a unique concept, combining card game, board game and RPG genres. I would have given this game a 10/10 but since there is no manual or tutorial it is more so a 9. However, when you finally figure out how the game works, it's loads of fun ( at times frustrating ;P ). It does not have minigames (like in Mario Party), so it is pretty much based on luck (which I don't have, hehe) and strategy. Overall, I loved the charming characters, the card play, battle system and the online play as well. It may seem a bit quirky if this isn't the kind of game you would normally play, but I do suggest trying it out, at least!

reviewText:
In reality I hate orange juice, especially with pulp. This board game however? Very nice.

The gameplay is easy to grasp and if you actually read the guide (which I didn't do at first) you pick up on the remaining details that you may have missed. The graphics are cute, and the tunes are very nice too. At it's core is the luck based dice rolling, though you can better influence the board with cards. There's an in-game card collection feature, which lets you get more cards to more consistantly rig your luck/ruin other people's days. But even when you're rolling 2 dice to move, dodge, attack... etc you can still roll just right to ruin/delay your win. And then again next turn.

There's a wide variety of characters to play with, you wont be limited to just playing the one you pick at the beginning in mutliplayer (not sure how the difficulty described with those four actually relates though). You can unlock more cute (and fun characters) just by playing the campaign AND/OR you can buy through DLC. I'm fond of the fact that DLC characters aren't automatically far better than any standard characters. Regardless of DLC or not, sometimes map events will make winning with a character maybe a little harder than you'd expect (Aru and a map with Charity for example).

reviewText:
Okay, I'll star tthis review with this: if you thought Mario Party was rage-inducing, you've never had victory stolen from you by Marie Poppo hyper just as you're about to get to your home base.

*ahem* now that I have that formality out of the way, on to the review.  This game is brilliant.  It combines dice rolling and battles in a neat little package that delivers hours of fun for you and friends or random strangers playing this game.

pros
- Marie Poppo
- nice cast of characters to choose from
- worth the money for DLC content and great pricing (it also goes on sale from time to time)
- Poppopopopopopopopo!
- currency system to buy in-game cards and other character custom colors, bosses and regular NPC enemies as playable characters (so release the inner chicken in you and fight the others!)
- unique character attributes and specials
- Did I mention Marie Poppo?
- story mode available to get used to the game and unlock other characters
- map variety
- build a deck of 10 cards to throw into the mix of other player's cards
- cards from the mixed pack DLC can be used by people who don't own the DLC as long as the cards are put in by a person who owns the DLC
- Seriously, Marie Poppo!

cons
- not all characters are given to you out the box
- the only way to earn levels is to play online games
- maps also must be purchased and unlocked based on level
- character colors also need to be purchased or earned while playing the game (not entirely bad though)
- you MUST buy card packs to get new cards
- some of the items can get expensive
- playing AGAINST Marie Poppo
- DLC for new characters and a new card pack set (however, the price per DLC is pretty inexpensive, so this is a minor con)

Gameplay is pretty straight forward and easy to understand.
The graphics are colorful, especially for a board game, and do their job.
The music is extrodinary, as every character has a set theme song associated with themselves.  Each player who completes a norma (objective) gets their music played for everyone to hear.
As I said before, the replay value is pretty high, as you can play against people online and every game is different with the differnt customizable decks you can make and use.  I will say this: the single-player storymode might seem a little unfair with the AI and RNG, but nonetheless, it's beatable.  Sometimes, the RNG can be extremely evil (rolling nothing but 1s or using a certain card that has an effect that ends on a KO and rolling nothing but low numbers (or in the case of one of my games I've played online, 3s).

In conclusion, those of you who love a good multiplayer game without being too serious should definitely check this one out.  It's fun for just about everyone, and the hilarity of screwing over your opponents with just the right card is most satisfying.

overall rating: 9.5/10 would Poppo all day

reviewText:
100% Orange Juice is basically a simple little RNG and strategy board game where the object of the game is to complete 5 normas (quests) to win. You can also have a max of 3 cards in your hand that you can use. Each card has a different cost and effect and you'll see by playing how they work. You compete against 3 other people or CPU and the quests are either to win battles or have a certain amount of stars. Either way, you need to get 5 completed before your opponents do to win.

I'm still not exactly sure what orange juice has to do with this game but that aside the game is actually pretty fun. I started the campaign without knowing the rules or how to play at all, and it took me 1.5 games to pretty much learn everything just by playing. With that being said, the game's rules are simple enough to get used to quickly and there are more multiplayer lobbies than you'd expect. By winning games you can also get points which you can spend in the games store to buy custimizations, card packs, characters, etc.

Overall, 100% Orange Juice is a casual little game that I would recommend to anyone if the price drops under $5.

Rating: 7.7/10
Recommend Price: Under $5

reviewText: A boardgame that is based on previous OJ game characters with a solid multiplayer, free play, and story. The game offers 18 unlockable characters and 6 dlc characters along with quite a few playable bosses. Each character has different stats and plays differently, so mastering each character or only a few will last the player a long while in singleplayer or multiplayer. The story missions are quite hard, but the fast forward feature makes it faster and easier than is expected. The player can unlock characters, skins, and cards to play in the shop. There are many cards to unlock as well, so building a deck and choosing cards is a big part of winning games. My only complaint is that all characters must be unlocked via story mode, making the multiplayer less playable until the story is completed. One of my favorite indie games and I plan to play it for a long while.

reviewText:
An anime-based strategy board game that combines combat and card playing in competition to achieve a chosen goal and earn the highest level. And I use the term strategy loosely, you will depend on luck... ALOT. Seriously, I mean, ALOT. You could be right about to win and just constantly keep getting the worst rolls until someone else catches up and wins ahead of you. You could get stunned for turns on end because every 'Random KO' card that keeps getting played lands right on you for no particular reason. It wouldn't be such a big deal if games didn't take forever to complete, around 20-60 minutes a game. I mean, the RNG is a problem in almost any board game but this game appears to be atleast 70-80% luck, 15% strategy, and the rest just relying on the other players not having a vendetta against you.

Even through it's flaws though I still can't stop playing it. The characters are all engaging and you can sort of build your strategy by placing your own cards in the global deck. You can choose to focus on turn-locking players, design your cards for pure combat, or design your cards to gain more stars. All excellent ways to win as you can level up either by having stars or having combat wins.

This game truly shines in it's PvP area, which really seems like the only truly enjoyable part about this game. Playing in PvE is one of the most annoying things as it seems like everything is set up just to make the player lose and the AI win, even on normal. In PvP you'll still see players that seem to win every single roll, I've been beaten by players 15 times in a row even when I've had +5 stats and they had no buffs. Almost any game I've played I'll be right about to win and the entire cosmos will seem to turn against me to make sure there is no hope for me to win.  Just somehow it seems much more enjoyable when you atleast have other players having just as bad luck as you are.

3/5
I'm about to win and the boss comes over and one-shots me. As soon as I revive a random player uses a KO card, then when I revive I get hit by two damage cards and the boss comes back and finishes me off then proceeds to win the game. You either love or hate the random number generator...

reviewText:
The best board game for masochistic weeaboos that find their lives empty and meaningless.
When I got this game, I was so bored with my life. I couldn't find enjoyment in the real world or on the internet. I spent my days doing nothing but rotting in front of my monitor, desperately searching for something that could reignite the spark of my life. Then I found 100% Orange Juice.

Now instead of my life being empty and meaningless by my own hand, my life is empty and meaningless by the cruel hand of fate (and mother♥♥♥♥ing marie popo). Gone are the days where I sat emptily looking for happiness. I now know that happiness does not exist. There is only the continuous traversal of the game board. There is suffering in the form of dice-based battles.

This game is merciless. It helps you understand just how futile your attempts at discovering meaning in your life are.

10/10 would convert to nihilism again.

reviewText:
100% Orange Juice Review
What kind of game is this? How do you play? What do you do?
100% orange juice is a bored game with trading card elements. You move around the board trying to complete one of two task, killing others or gathering stars. You gather/lose stars by landing on spaces and rolling a die. You kill people by rolling a die to attack, and defend. You collect a portion of their stars if you kill them. Cards play a role by allowing you to build decks. You will draw a card from yor deck every time you land on a specific space. Cards can deal damage, give stat buffs, of be hidden traps on spaces.

Controls
This game is controlled entirely by the mouse; it works just fine. 10/10

Sound
The game sounds fine and the voice acting is pretty good, with options to change the voice, or turn it off. 10/10

Graphics
The game is not graphically intensive, and will run fine on almost any machine. The game has no 3D sprites, but looks great anyway. 10/10

Difficulty The difficulty is not regulated too well. It has options, but when it comes down to it, it’s an RNG determining your fate half the time. 6/10

Story
The story doesn’t matter at all. The game has several story lines for each character. None of them are fantastic, but they don’t need to be. 7/10

Multiplayer
The game works well in online multiplayer, it is the ideal way to play. 10/10

Overall this game is a great multiplayer experience, but you can play single player to grind for new cards and got some practice. (Learning how to play cards and where you should go next in your play style.) This game gets an 8/10. Strongly Recommended, especially with friends.

reviewText:
In reality I hate orange juice, especially with pulp. This board game however? Very nice.

The gameplay is easy to grasp and if you actually read the guide (which I didn't do at first) you pick up on the remaining details that you may have missed. The graphics are cute, and the tunes are very nice too. At it's core is the luck based dice rolling, though you can better influence the board with cards. There's an in-game card collection feature, which lets you get more cards to more consistantly rig your luck/ruin other people's days. But even when you're rolling 2 dice to move, dodge, attack... etc you can still roll just right to ruin/delay your win. And then again next turn.

There's a wide variety of characters to play with, you wont be limited to just playing the one you pick at the beginning in mutliplayer (not sure how the difficulty described with those four actually relates though). You can unlock more cute (and fun characters) just by playing the campaign AND/OR you can buy through DLC. I'm fond of the fact that DLC characters aren't automatically far better than any standard characters. Regardless of DLC or not, sometimes map events will make winning with a character maybe a little harder than you'd expect (Aru and a map with Charity for example).

reviewText: I thought that this game might be fun for me and my friends. This game is pretty hard. Luckily, me and my friends aren't bad losers. We play this game together and laugh at every sudden turn of events. This boardgame is a lot luck-based but pretty strategic as well. But because this game is luck-based, all my friends win once and a while keeping it fun. I bought the four-pack for 5 euro's, thinking I would get an hour of 3-5 in the game with friends. Time goes by extremely fast playing this game. And that's good. It's means I'm having fun. It makes me think of strategies, try new characters en have fun with my friends. If you're into games that are pretty much luck-based and just want to have fun. Buy this game, on sale is best.\n\nBonus: Have a look at the community hub for art. Lots of jokes about the hated playable character: Mariepoppo. You'll understand within an hour why.

reviewText:
I really enjoy this game. With Online it is even more fun when other users chat back and just relax.
Multiplayer is where this game shines and I love the community!

However you are thrown into the game without any tutorial other than you looking up a guide yourself but it is not hard to get the hang of things such as learn what does what. This makes it easy for you to decide which character is best for what map and also plan a strategy to help you win easier.

Bewarned however this game is not easy, on campaign mode even on casual you can easily get beaten either by lack of rolls or an NPC using their hyper card to steal/kill you and snag the win. This game wants you to think and be on your toes so no easy ride here. This is no Mario Party. One wrong mistake and it can cost you the win.
Campaign is there to unlock characters, each campaign can unlock all characters but one so check the shop after every campaign or so to see if the character is buyable. Even if you lose the character can still be buyable.

A lot of this relays on your luck of the draw with some skill which a party game like this should do. After the first campaign it does get easier due to your knowledge of the game but if you get easily angry I suggest online mode with others, it is less stressfull.

Overall I give this 8/10
It is a party game where you have to actually be lucky with some strategy which a board game like this should be. Unlike Mario Party which is mostly down to skills in mini-games and rarely any luck.
Multiplayer is where it shines and even the starting characters can beat the unlockable characters.

I am happy I bought the 4-pack to gift to my friends and they already adore this game.

reviewText: 100% Orange Juice (OJ) is rather well-done and holds a high position in replayability. It features characters from the Orange Juice universe, and even some original characters of its own. 100% OJ has cards that are used during gameplay, as well as an RNG-based movement and combat system determined by the roll of a die. Hono's character illustrations display the playable characters well, in all of their poses. Truly a game environment where you can make friends and I would recommend this game to anyone interested!

reviewText:
★ HYAKU PAASENTO ORENJI JUUSU! ★ I just can't get over the fuzzy feelings I get every time the game greets me in that adorable voice.

This game only came out yesterday, but I'm already having plenty of fun with my friends. 100% OJ is a game that depends heavily on your RNG (luck, basically) in order to win. Sure, selecting a decent deck helps, but nothing will save you if your dice rolls suck! In a way, it's nostalgic of games like Mario Party but with the indie developer (think Recettear) sort of atmosphere / feeling. It makes for a lot of fun between good friends, as long as no one is the sore loser type~

Hell, if you're old enough, I'd even recommend playing it over a few drinks.

Play on, everyone!  ღゝ◡╹)ノ♡

You remember those days of screaming across the room at your friends while playing Mario Party?

Get ready to re-live those days. After only a few hours of playing multiplayer with a few friends; Heads shall be rolling;

reviewText:
100% Salty.

I've played mario party with hardcore ultra-competitive types. The kind of people who practice the mini-games and expect no less of you. I have seen saltyness that would make looking back at sodom seem low sodium heart friendly. This game puts all that to shame. Every character has a unique way to be annoying as ♥♥♥♥. Every map has a way of ♥♥♥♥ing you over. You can choose to prioritize coins or combat to complete normas (akin of getting stars in mario party) but you'll always complete the one you didn't select first.

In short 10/10 perfect party game.

What I found instead was quite interesting.

100% Orange Juice is a computer board game that roughly works like a cross between monopoly and munchkin, although it has MANY things which make it unique, at least from anything I've ever played before. Throughout an entire game session, dice-battles and star-collecting (stars are the currency of the game) occur on every turn, but the game is only won once five goals (or normas"

recommended: which is determined by the number of stars or the number of enemies beaten. What's very nice about the norma system is that you can chose between either of the two goals

reviewText:
It's pretty fun if you've got friends to play it with or can find an open lobby. The method of unlocking characters is to beat the campaign mode, which is a little time-consuming even if you do hold down ctrl + shift to skip most of it. Once you have them unlocked you don't ever need to do that again, though, so it's about 1-2 hours of your life lost to have more fun in multiplayer.

And boy, is multiplayer fun. This is a Mario Party or Dokapon Kingdom-esque game that takes elements from both - You 'level up' via stars or wins and the first to reach 14 wins or 200 stars is the winner... Provided they can make it back to a 'home space' before they're killed or worse. There is combat, both against the environment and other players, and there's a decent cast of characters that fit several roles - PvP oriented, star collection oriented, and a mix of both. I've had a lot of fun with this game, and I'll probably keep playing it for a long time.

Definitely recommended!
