reviewText:
100% orange juice is a casual card/board game. That has a cute anime chibi theme to it, from the characters you play, to the cards you use.

Gameplay: 8

The game play here is pretty solid. You start off with a character, then you build a deck of cards that is used in the main game. Once everyone has made there decks the game will start. Once in the main game everyone's decks are placed into one pile in the middle of the current board. Which will be used to draw cards from. So that mean you can draw other players cards while they can draw your own. You'll find your self playing on different boards that can have a different setup each time you play. Each board has there own board event" from doubling up on Star
hoursPlayed: to being randomly teleported to a different square and much more.\n\nYou have 6 different square types. Home
voteText: Card draw
helpfulPercent: star bonus
votesHelpful: star lost
votesTotal: monsters
votesFunny: and teleports. most of these are self explanatory. Home is where your character starts the game off at. Home also is used to accept and complete missions also While it can heal you or anyone else for one hp if landed on it.  However one of the benefits about your own home is no matter what you roll if you end up going to it or passing it they game will allow you to stop at your own home and if you do so
commentsCount: you won't be able to use the rest of your movement. Monster squares are two fold. Monster Squares are events where you end up fighting a basic monster to gain more stars. But be careful they will fight back and knock you out resulting in you losing half your own stars. After so many turns every monster square will turn into a monster boss square which spawns harder monsters to take down but gives a greater star bonus when defeated. After a boss has been defeated all monster squares goes back to normal monster squares.\n\nYou start a new game off with one card that is drawn from the deck in the middle. You are able to get more by landing on the green squares. Some card require you to pay and/or have the right level to use it. While many different card types to be used like Traps
column16: Hypers
column17: battle
column19: and boost. Each can effect the game differently while adding more strategy to your game plan.\n\nCharacters have there own character cards that shows there stats to attack
column21: Evade and HP while some have card Ability’s. Every character has there own hyper card that is unique to them
column22: However it is possible for other players to take this card from you and use it.\n\nThe goal of the game is two fold. Either win by having 200 or more stars
column23: or winning fights between monsters and other players. At the start of the game each player starts off at level one. To be able to level up you must complete missions either by collection enough stars or winning enough fights. The high level you can become is level five.\n\nCombat in this game is determine by a dice roll on a d6( a six sided die). When entering combat with a player or a monster your allowed to choose one card from your hand that can altar the fight
column24: Keep in mind that only certain cards can be played during combat. The attacking player will always go first. While in combat your base stats will effect your rolls. When someone attacks the defending player or monster they have a chance of rolling either a Defend or an Evade roll. Each one plays out differently. While choosing a defend roll you Subtract your roll to the damage that is being inflicted on your character to a minimum of one damage. While Evading you MUST roll at least one number higher than the current attack number to avoid taking all damage
column25: If you roll equal or less than the attack you will take the full on coming damage to your character. Both sides will be given a chance to attack and defend. However there can only be one attack and one defend roll for each side. There are cards that can effect this however. When fighting a fellow player
column26: if you successfully knock them out you will gain half of there stars into your own pool. After a player is knocked out
column27: every turn that comes they will need to roll to be brought back up
column28:
if they fail to get back up the rest of there turn is skipped.

Now the bad part about the game play is the RNG (Random number generator) factor. However do not let this discourage. There will be times you feel like the game is cheating you while other time you feel like things are playing out in your favor. If you get easily upset or take game seriously then this game is NOT for you. This game is a fun casual game that almost anyone can pick up and play. And If you don't mind the RNG factor then you might find this game to your liking.

When finishing your current game
column29: every star you have collected will be added to your game profile to be used in the store. The store is where you buy booster packs
column32:
and boards. However the bad part about the store is that you must level up your profile to unlock more stuff from with in the store. To do this you have to play online with either friends or random players. It's not much of a big deal really but it still would of been nice to have a leveling up system in single player for the people who are just wanting a fun quick game and not have to play with others. However this is still a minor thing.

Graphics: 7

The graphics in the game are very colourful with an anime style look and feel to them. All the characters are chibi form. The game has very playful and inviting graphics that is simple but yet nice to look at.

The only real problem i can see with the graphics is when you are playing on a board the background has the same repeating design over and over. It's nothing major. Some people may find it distracting or annoying.

Music: 8

The soundtrack is great mix of easy listening music
column34:
to anime style music. One thing that can be a problem is while playing the music can repeat it's self over and over again.


Story: 3

The story is all over the place. There is no real “story” being told here. Every character you can play as has a some what of mini-story to it. The story’s are mostly a random reason to play the game with other NPC's you end up meeting. Some of the reason can be cute and funny.

Online: -

I normally don't review online play for games. However with how the game is setup it forces you play online to unlock more stuff as I stated above. Over all it doesn't bother me that I have to play online. However I believe a game shouldn't force you into playing online to unlock everything. There are much worse examples out there that does this than this game does.


Final though. I give this game a 8 out of 10.

While this game is very casual and fun

reviewText:
100% Orange Juice is a RNG based board-game consisting of achieving several objectives to achieve your goal while prevents your opponents from accomplishing theirs in the process. At first glance 100% Orange Juice would seem realatively due to your outcomes being determined by Dice however once you continue to play you will discover this game has alot of complexity behind it.

This game has high replayability due to it's many maps and cards aswell as many characters to select from, this results in the possibility of alot of interesting matches to occur. The art style is very chibi/anime like, the devs used past characters from other titles as alot of their base characters. This game offers solid progress through a satisfying leveling system which allows you to continue buying items from the shop to alter you experience such as booster packs which will potientally give you a powerful card or additional maps and characters who can alter you experience significantly.

Even though 100% Orange Juice is RNG based it is all up to how you take you approach to a situation that will influence your outcome, your main objective will be to take every advantage you can and utilize all the options that are avalible to you.

I recommend this game if you can find a couple of friends willing to fight againest you, your enjoyment will be increased with friends, however the campaign is also decent and allows you to versus AI and many different maps and follow a nonsensical story containing alot of humour. If you enjoy board games in general perhaps you will enjoy this game.

Overall 100% Orange Juice is an enjoyable experience if your willing to give it a chance to see what it has to offer and deserves a 7/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There are three key factors that keep me coming back to this game. First off the gameplay itself is just fun, ESPECIALLY the multiplayer. I'd recommend either finding some people that frequent the game, or do what i did and badger your friends into buying copies. XD The price is cheap enough, and you get more than enough bang for the buck.

Secondly, the length of each match is PERFECT. Other games in the genre like mario party or dokapon kingdom were fun but had the tendency to destroy everything you worked for at the drop of a hat. Nothing is quite as rage inducing as watching an hour of your progress flushed away in a matter of seconds. 100% Orange Juice will still give you these moments, but the matches tend to last 10-15 minutes at the most. This alone makes getting screwed over at the last minute much more bearable. Even better, most of the unlockables are able to be obtained via multiplayer. I enjoyed campaign mode, but some of my friends would rather play multiplayer. It's nice to have that option.

Third, the developer's support for this game is outstanding. They've added so much free content to the game and continue to do so. Take a look at the update logs for the major patches if you've got the time. It's just about everything you could think of for an online board game. The original game looks ancient compared to the version out now! The game certainly has enough to keep you playing; I haven't come close to unlocking all the extras they've added.

Out of all my steam games, I'd say this game held my attention longer than the vast majority of them. I have highly recommended it to friends, and I highly recommend you give it a shot.

reviewText: Wacky fun. That's really the best way to describe it. A 2D digital board game made solely for the anime-girl enthusiast, you and three other players collect cards, gold, and experience from traveling around a flat map and killing monsters and each other. Unfortuantely, the game isn't really self explanatory and it helps to play with friends when figuring out how things work. Each player has a set of cards that they put into the game deck, which are then shuffled and dealt out to players randomly. These cards can either hurt a player by dealing damage, heal damage, lay traps, give coins, etc... The players take turns moving around the board and landing on spaces, which give coins, cards, or spawn monsters where the player must fight with dice rolls. You can also fight other players to make them lose their next turn, or lose gold and slowing down their progression in levels. The objective is to level up to level 5 first, by either killing enough people/monsters to get experience or by collecting coins from spaces and other players. There's definitely a difficulty curve, but the online multiplayer is surprisingly very stable.\n\nThe art might turn people off at first, but at the end of the day this makes for a very fun game to play online with your friends.

reviewText:
If you like being subjected to the cruel sense of humor of the RNGod, then boy is this the game for you.

I wouldn't recommend playing this game alone, it's best played with friends or acquaintances, because it's a board game, the more the merrier. The luck aspect of the game just makes it so much more fun and frustrating, and it has given me plenty of laughs.

Games go by fast enough if you set the speed to 4, and you always should if you ask me, so it's not that time consuming if you want to play something with people and don't have an hour or so to sink into something else.

reviewText:
UPDATE: The developers of this game are great and are always releasing new versions with bug fixes or even free additional content. As such, they've added support for higher resolutions and as far as I can see (can't confirm this 100% yet, but it seems to be the case) the problems I faced below appear to be fixed. I can only recommend this game now. I'm starting to play it again and they've even added chat support in multiplayer. It has a nice community and it's fun to play online. I'd recommend using the casual mode for the single player campaign though. Any higher setting and the dice rolls are pre-determined I believe.

---

If you have a dual-screen setup, reconsider. If you don't, this is a fun game and you should buy it. However, it has serious crash problems for dual-screen (or more) players. Most of the problems lie in the fact that if you click a pixel off the game's full screen, it starts flickering like crazy and after about ten seconds, closes. This is because it doesn't have any kind of mouse cursor locking; in other words, the mouse cursor does not stay in the game window.

This problem can mostly (I've had crashes unrelated to this) be averted by using the smaller windowed mode. This is not an option for me, though. I use my computer for non-gaming purposes in my lounge, but when gaming I play in my cinema room on the sofa. The card descriptions are very low resolution, and since I don't have the option of bringing my head close to the screen, I can't read the text unless using full-screen mode. On that note, I use a 2.4GHz mouse to play the game since it doesn't support gamepads.

If you have a single monitor or you're happy with windowed mode, go for it. This is just a warning. It's a fun game (a bit masochistic when the AI cheats) and the reviews speak truth. The developers are also friendly and responsive. However, until they fix these problems, I don't think I can play this game. It ends up as a waste of time with crashes near the end of long games, etc.

reviewText:
0% Luck in 100% Orange Juice

When I played this game for the first time, I didn't read the guide so me and my friend had no idea what we were doing xD, but it was actually easy to learn the rules by playing 1 game. After more hours of gameplay, this game became more competitive and fun to play. Playing with friends is even better and the story mode is all goods to play. Tricks will be used, everyones luck will be random, and Seagulls will destroy you. My personal favourite board game ever.

-Easy to learn system
-Awesome card abilites
-Hard NPCs
-Variety of characters to play
-Chickens and seagulls that can wreack
-Tears friendships apart
-Praying for a roll of 6
-There is no orange Juice in the game

9/10

reviewText:
Hot Japanese ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t Lives!  But in the best way possible.

If you've ever had the baffling thrill of grabbing a random, Japanese tabletop style video game from an import shop or online (particularly in the heyday of the Dreamcast), then 100% Orange Juice is like a visit from a long lost friend.

The rules are, without the instructions, indecipherable for the first 5 minutes. Then slowly you start to understand... and then realize you didn't understand, but you're winning... you think... and then the computer does something nuts and they win.

And it seems like the game is aware of it! Play the demo. You'll take the role of a character who has had his wallet stolen by a girl who only says 'Popopo'. Amidst this nonsense, your character is able to deduce she stole your wallet and you have to challenge her to a battle. After winning the game, your character actually asks What happened? Who won?".

Visually the game has a nice
date: colorful style. Not a ton of animation
hoursPlayed: but totally acceptable. 100% Orange Juice has a crazy
voteText: MIDI sax and bass soundtrack that was very commonplace in most early 2000's import games. The far-east-space-jazz is punctuated with high pitched anime screams
helpfulPercent: and seiyu voice overs
votesHelpful: exactly like you need it to be.\n\nThe publisher is a genius for localizing this game
votesTotal: and not bothering with localized audio.\n\nFor the gameplay
votesFunny: most of the reviews I've seen I agree with; It's unfair

The rules are, without the instructions, indecipherable for the first 5 minutes. Then slowly you start to understand... and then realize you didn't understand, but you're winning... you think... and then the computer does something nuts and they win.

And it seems like the game is aware of it! Play the demo. You'll take the role of a character who has had his wallet stolen by a girl who only says 'Popopo'. Amidst this nonsense, your character is able to deduce she stole your wallet and you have to challenge her to a battle. After winning the game, your character actually asks What happened? Who won?".

Visually the game has a nice
date: colorful style. Not a ton of animation
hoursPlayed: but totally acceptable. 100% Orange Juice has a crazy
voteText: MIDI sax and bass soundtrack that was very commonplace in most early 2000's import games. The far-east-space-jazz is punctuated with high pitched anime screams
helpfulPercent: and seiyu voice overs
votesHelpful: exactly like you need it to be.\n\nThe publisher is a genius for localizing this game
votesTotal: and not bothering with localized audio.\n\nFor the gameplay
votesFunny: most of the reviews I've seen I agree with; It's unfair
column16: rage inducing
column17: awesome
column18: and so much fun to play. It's like a guy who plays too much Chutes and Ladders
column19: met a guy who is obsessed with Risk. They went to CoCo Ichiban in Akihabara
column21: and decided to make a video game combining their passions.\n\nAnd instead of the light-RPG elements that you might expect
column23: and it's fun to unlock booster packs!\n\nStay wierd
column24: Japan. The world needs you more than ever."

reviewText: 100% Orange Juice is a boardgame kinda thing made with the characters of orange_juice's previous game. orange_juice is a doujin maker, For those who dont know. The goal in each game is to get 200 stars or 14 kills, Or both if RNG-sama loves you. The first to do so and land on their home wins, Pretty strait forward and simple. But lets be honest here, Nobody actually plays for some hardcore epic mlg gameplay. Everybody who plays this game really just play it for the good comunity. The orange_juice comunity is one of the more friendly and good comunitys out there, But when it comes to this game some people can get salty if RNG is a ♥♥♥♥♥. This is more of a nice pass time to spend with your friends with a nice game in the backround than a grab your icecream, ditch your family and wast your life away kinda game. This game is one of my favorite games due to many of the reasons i just listed. You will meet many good friends in this game too, I mean look at my 40+ friends that came from just this game. Of course you get bad people to (AHEM *cough* sci) that infect everybody and its a war to stay alive near them. But that isnt as frequent as making friends with this game. Now but this game, And tread carefully my friend, For you may find a poppo, Or worse... A summoner....

reviewText: 100% OJ is an interesting take on screwing your friends(or enemies) over in a traditional board game format brought to pc. Players each have a home tile and roll dice to move which can have several different outcomes such as fight a monster, earn free stars, lose stars, draw a card, teleport, and nothing. Once your goals are met you need to stop on your home tile or land on someone elses, and once you complete five norma" (which are your self proclaimed missiosn such as get 100 stars or beat 9 enemies) you win. Conflict is solved by the attacker rolling a die
date: and the defender rolling a die after picking defend and evade with certain cards offering powerups.\n\nAll in all this is a good game to play with friends to end your friendship
recommended: or to play with random people in the many different online servers to create new enemies."

reviewText:
Poppo stole my heart, my time, and my pudding.

100% Orange Juice is a lighthearted game of dice, in which you play as one of a large selection of unique characters.  It offers a large variety of fun and interesting playstyles, all of which will inevitably still be at the mercy of the cruel, unfeeling wrath of the RNG.

Pros:
+Lots of characters with ongoing support from Fruitbat Factory to maintain game balance
+They finally added a random filter to allow you to turn certain maps, characters, and field events off while still maintaining an exciting sense of unpredictability
+DLC done right--not required to enjoy the game, but provides interesting elements to gameplay
+Game doesn't take itself too seriously, and neither does its community.
+The AI will inevitably do something so ridiculous that you can't help but roll your eyes and laugh
+Excellent game to play with friends
+Manageable Achievements--While there are a couple you'll need to boost for, none are at the level of being tedious

Cons:
-Fernet, QP, and Softened Tomomo
-Singleplayer campaign required to unlock all characters, but will make you want to pull your hair out
-Associated difficulties for initial character choice are misleading, causing many newbies to pick QP when Marc is a much more newbie-friendly choice.

reviewText:
With only seven hours in the game as of the writing of this review I am pleasantly suprised at how much fun this game is turning out to be.

Singleplayer
It was fun. You get to see characters and cards you haven't unlocked yet. Not nearly as much as multplayer from what I have seen so far. For me it kinda lacked a competitive aspect being against CPUs and all.
Played some campaign. Not enough to really draw a conclusion.
Multiplayer
Just recently started to get into the multiplayer of this game. My experience so far has been better and more fun for me than singleplayer. It has a good balance of competition. Whether I win or lose each game doesnt feel like a slug fest and I find myself wanting to play more. I have learned more playing with other people and seeing what they do with the characters. It's also nice because you get to see characters and cards you haven't unlocked and try them out. Games are easy to host and join which is a plus.
Soundtrack
The soundtrack is beautiful. I love all the songs. Although my two favorites are Hime's theme and Suguri's theme.
Visuals
The game is great looking. I enjoy it's art style.
Overall
I would definitly recommend this game to others. So far I am getting more fun out of this game than I expected I would. The game is a nice break from the casual games I usually use to get over losing streaks in Dota 2. Losing doesn't feel as bad in this game. I shall expand this review as I play more. Also this is my first review. I know I am missing some important aspects of the game. I just felt the need to post a review for it.

reviewText:
Description: 100% Orange Juice a game that pulls characters together from other games that Orange_Juice have created into a single game of crazy board game goodness. This game is basically summed as a board game meets card game. It has a few scenarios for a story mode with some extra/challenge scenarios after the scenarios to round out a decent pure singleplayer phase. The game is prefered for it's multiplay, it's multiplayer is for up to 4 people with cpu players filling in the blank spots and with some fun rewards you can unlock from multiplayer instead of playing the scenarios. There is also a free play mode to just jump in and play some against some cpu players instead of playing scenarios again and again or going into multiplayer.

Good: It's a fun game with tons of replay to it. It's great for casual time wasting as well as just something for you and your friends to get together and play for a fun game night. The music for the game is fantastic as well ranging from simple little beats in the menus to jazz and techno/dance for character themes. The visuals are pleasing (if you apreciate cutesy animu). The cards all have fantastic art on them from comical to stunning. Flavor text on each card is a fun read some with refrences to the games they are orignally from to just fun little things. Fantastic thing is for a board game, there is a speed setting in which you can set how fast the animations flow in order to speed up each action in order to not have the game drag on from just waiting on the animations to stop (lots of animations from dice rolls, to card use, movement, and so on).

Bad: The game is extremely RNG (like all board games) I am putting it into the bad becasue alot of people tend to rage at RNG and their horrible luck (basically here is your fair warning). Like Mario Party and Mario Kart back in the day, this game can destroy friendships if you are way to competetive. The anouncer can get alittle annoying constantly hearing the cutesy voice call out what panel you are landing on and which players turn it is (mainly because it steps on the music man, so good!).

TL;DR: Great little animu board game to get together with friends and play just for the funzies. Great music, fun interesting art and visuals, can be very competetive if you are that kind of player, and VERY RNG!

I give it from my own personal tastes as well as the factors stated above,

9.5/10 Game as a whole
10 waifus out of 10 For Animu goodness
12 out of 10 For great music

Cooperate with your friends to beat a boss.
Your friends kill you.
You kill two friends in a row, then land on battle panel and lose by chicken.
Get rekt by seagulls who ALWAYS ROLL 6.
Lose cards in your hand.
Poppo will jack you stars whenever possible.
Have a feeling that this time you will win.
Then someone suddenly land on you.
RNG God never smile at you.
Rage quit.
10/10 would roll again.

reviewText:
This game is super anime which is terrible because I'm not 12. The concept seems pretty cool. It's a board game where the objective is to hit certain milestones in number of enemies defeated or in amount of stars you gain from doing pretty much anything. You choose a deck of cards to bring with you that tend to affect all players and are gotten from various squares on the board and can use the aforementioned stars to buy boosters of more cards.

I played the campaign some and considering it has a similar friendship destroying reputation as Mario Party, I'm gonna give the multiplayer a pass. Every sound effect is grating after hearing them repeated for 45 minutes straight. Get it if you like card games and board games and anime.

Verdict: It's a game

reviewText:
Looking for some fun or rage against you're friends or the AI? Well nearly every game like this will do that but this one seems to have a nice balance. With a lot of events and mechanics made fair to everyone (RNG seagulls away!) the game combines a mix of strategy/ play making that is combined with some RNG's to win.

The game is visually appealing in any eye in my opinion, as cartoonish art styles can last a lot longer then any high end cawa dooty graphics can. and the music is fairly vast with tracks for each character and board.

100% Orange juice is pretty much a mix between Mario party and Dokapon kingdom in terms of mechanics so if that's what you're looking for at a cheap price then you got the party game for you and you're friends (seriously the 4 pack is basically 2 packs for free and thats a cool deal).

Boardgame video games like this rarely show up on the PC which makes them a great treat when they do make them for PC.

10/10 would recommend for anyone looking for a party board game on the PC!

reviewText: Welcome to Orange Juice's Board game where you and your friends (or imaginary friends if you dont have them) can have a fun time playing a game of dice\n\nBefore i say anything... This is actually a crossover game between their already existing games like flying red barrel"
recommended:
"QP shooting" and some others i probably dont remember but now onto the review

100% orange juice is like i said a board game made by orange juice and localised by Fruit Bat Factory
So the first time you look at it you are probably thinking "hey this look like fortune street and or mario party" but this game uses a stars and card system much like mario party's items and coins but rather than trying to collect as many stars you can you have to "level up" your norma level... how would you do that you ask? you can level up the first time by gaining 10 stars and further down a line pick between battling and collecting more stars but im sorry if you are reading this since i have a hard time not explaining everything

this game allows you to create a deck of a few cards that do various things as well as use character that all have various stats and plenty of campaigns to go through. as i havent beaten my first campaign yet there are 4 characters you can pick from to start with each of them having some sort of penalty and buff to themselves as well as their own hyper card which are mixed into the deck (hyper cards can only be drawn by their specific character but if you draw a hyper card the other players will have a lower chance of drawing one themselves) you can obtain said cards by earning stars by winning or losing a game and buying packs of cards much like a trading card game and before you ask... there is no such thing as trading but... you can trade the cards you earn on steam... that counts right?

so you heard me mention about stats
in this game rather than mini games you get battles as i mentioned before being one of the requirements you can pick to level up

so in battles you have 3 base stats atk
hoursPlayed:
def and evasion and you each get to roll your dice once (unless a card says so otherwise) the player who starts the battle goes first and has roll for atk if you roll a 6 you have a 6 hit atk simple as that but the second player defending is able to defend or evade if you defend the same thing as atk applies if you roll a 6 you take only 1 damage but if you choose to evade you can negate the damage completely by rolling higher than the amount of atk but if you roll lower than the atk you take the full damage ofcourse the stats on your characters are applies to these actions if you have +1 atk you get you dice result +1 as the same thing counts for defence and evasion

but enough talking about how the game plays out because im pretty sure i confused you all enough and explained too much about the game

the game in general can be pretty pretty hard depending on your dice rolls and the a.i is going to try and take you down and each character follows a specific pattern or behaviour and tends to try and prevent you from winning as much as you can

thanks to the localization team the online of this game is improved by alot compared to its original release
because in the english version you have lobbies that are supported by steam and makes it alot easier to set something up with your friends and maybe even strangers and online you get to level up and earn exp which was never implemented in the original game

in general i really think you should get this game if you like board games
its a fun game and it doesnt take itself seriously

if i ruined the game for you i take all responsibility but dont hate me for it... hey maybe if your lucky you will bump into me online"

reviewText:
If you're into the whole 'Kawaii-Ness' of japanese chibi characters, then this game is already worth it.
Despite having gotten it during the summer 2014 steam sale, I would of easily bought this at its' full price, due to the fun and interest in the game.

The game itself is basically a form of board game where you have to complete tasks (normas) either by getting 'stars' (granted by either the end of a 'chapter' by defeating a CPU, Player, or Flash Enemy, or by landing on a bonus tile), or by getting wins (granted by defeating a CPU, Player, or Flash Enemy).

You're allowed to start of as four different characters (Sugure, QP, Kai, and Marc) and progress through their campaigns, which allows you to amass star points, which can then be used to unlock other characters which are unlocked for buying through the campaigns. Each character has a different specialty in terms of skills (Attack, Defense, and Evasion) and each have different hypers (Unique skills that attune to a specific character, an example being Marc's 16x Big Cannon, which damages a specific character in attunement with how many 'star levels' that Marc has.)

Overall, the game is filled with kawaii, board games, a little bit of friendly murderous rivalry, and a lot of fun.

reviewText:
I used to have scurvy but then I bought this game and I was k.

But really, I thought this game was 100% luck at first. Then you play it a bit and realize that a lot of the skill comes from risk managment and thoughtful consideration for available options. There is a surprisingly large amount of decisions that you have to make  for a game that is very much based on dice. But with the inclusion of a hand of cards and the ability to halt your movement on certain spots instead of just passing over them. You can actually be GOOD at this game.

That being said low rollin will hurt your soul and make you cry so get ready for Mario Party/Monopoly levels of Salt.

reviewText:
My new favorite board game. Also, a lackluster TCG and fast-paced RPG.
Do not be fooled by the cutesy graphics. This is a very well-developed game.

Starting with the trading card game elements, there aren't very many cards and there's no trading. Still, this game uses a rather clever solution for balance: each player picks a handful of cards from their own collection and those get put into a communal deck to be used by any player. When selecting cards, you have to weigh the value of how much it can help you if you get it against the impact of it being used by another player. Card types include boost
hoursPlayed: and unit" cards.\n\nOn the RPG side of things
voteText: there are a few selectable characters who each have their own short
helpfulPercent: comedic story
votesHelpful: but these stories aren't really focused on enough to be factored into the decision to purchase the game. Each character has different stats; one has +0 to all stats while another has +2 attack and -1 defense and evasion while yet another has +1 to all while having reduced HP. These stats can only be changed temporarily by using cards; there are no stat level ups
votesTotal: which helps keep things from getting too imbalanced. Having low values for all these stats helps make combat go faster. The stats are added to the value of die rolls to determine damage
votesFunny: and when you only have ~5 max HP
commentsCount: every point matters. Each character also has their own unique "hyper" ability that is activated by cards in the communal deck.\nDuring combat
column16: the attacker rolls first. The defender then chooses whether to defend or attempt to evade. After the aggressor's attack
column17: the victim then counterattacks with the same mechanics if they were not slain.\nWhile the characters do not gain experience
column20: you (the player) do. Each match played online gives experience based on how well you ended up doing and level ups unlock more stuff to purchase in the shop including more characters.\n\nThe boardgame mixes strategy with luck. There's enough luck involved that a player who is down is not truly out until the game's finished
column21: and a player with a large lead is not safe until landing on the finish. I've seen many examples of come-from-behind victories and large leads falling to pieces
column22: and these ups and downs help keep the game fun and interesting when playing with other players. As far as strategy goes
column23: you can pick routes when the path branches (altering the distance to home)
column24: you pick when to play cards
column25: and when passing another player you can choose to stop on their square and battle them with victory awarding you half their stars and +2 win points. The goal of the game is to meet an ever increasing goal of either stars or combat wins (player's choice) and reach a home point to turn in that goal (and thus reach the next goal tier
column27: earning victory when cleared). Wins always go up but can be difficult to get while stars are easier to earn yet just as easy to lose. There are also plenty of boards with very different layouts which helps the game stay fun after multiple play sessions.\n\nThe game is mostly suited for online play (though it does have a single player campaign and free mode)
column28: and it has a few things of note in that area. The game uses Steam servers to form lobbies and you can have a match with random players. During a normal turn
column29: you get 60 seconds before the AI takes over for you
column30: so it's not too much of a problem if players leave their keyboard for a bit. When attacked
column31: you are given 40 seconds to decide what to do
column32: but the other player's clock freezes after they make a choice
column33: so you can't outwait them for the sake of taking advantage of enemy AI. When doing a revival roll
column35:
Fruitbat Factory has been quite active in the community as well as busy adding content and rebalancing things.

Verdict:
The game looks quirky enough that I wouldn't normally recommend it
column36: but it makes for one heck of a cheap party game. If you and up to 3 friends are looking for a casual game to play online in which all players remain on equal ground and can get this cheap

reviewText: 100% Orange Juice is a party board game, the most comparable video game being Mario Party, but 100% OJ stands well as it's own game with unique gameplay features. Players choose cards to enter into the pool of powerups. Choosing a card does not guarantee that the cards a player enters will return to them, essentially making the different collection of card between players fair. Instead of minigames 100% OJ has a simple battle system that initiates when a player lands on an enemy encounter space or passes another player while moving on the game board. The battle system is simple, roll more than the other player while attacking to kill and roll more on the defense to take reduced damage or evade damage altogether. Fighting becomes tiresome whoever when the game tosses the character Tomomo" into the game during the campaign mode. Tomomo makes the game a perfect allegory for life. All the 1s rolled to move or during combat let the player experience bad luck. After playing 100% OJ players will be able to empathize with the ugly ♥♥♥♥ers who lost the genetic roullette and hate the beatiful people who lucked out due to their supreme genes. Tomomo needs to ♥♥♥♥ off with these 8 rolls when I fight her. I thought I was done with this ♥♥♥♥ after Fire Emblem I just want to beat the campaign so I can unlock the characters so I can play with my friends online with new characters and maps if you manage to get me in a game and play Tomomo you can gladly ♥♥♥♥ off I'm removing you from my friends list and blocking you."

reviewText:
If you did not already figure it out, the name IS a word play on: 100% RNG. Which of course means: 100% Random Generator. And you will definatly feel that as you play. This little boardgame /cardgame is about rolling dice, moving around a board, fight the other players, collect stars and play cards from your hand with different effects. And of course you can gain levels and buy new cards within the game in booster packs. All to create a tiny but … a surprisingly fun game.

But this is one of those games that you should definatly play with your friends. All the randomnes of the different situations that occur throughout a round of play will definatly bring a smile to your faces. And as your tiny chibi-like characters run across the board you will want to continue hunting down those other players and points and cards and scores and... so on.

Even tho the game is random and alot of players will state that it is ALL random, you do actually have a few desicsions that still makes the game somewhat strategic. You can often decide to walk in a certain direction on the board, you build a deck of cards that goes in to the pool of cards that players can draw from, you decide on which goal you want to go for during the game and you decide which cards to play and when to play them. So there are desicions to be made! A lot mor than you would originally think anyway...

If you already love tiny random games with cute art and very positive music. Go ahead and get this game! If you don't... well you're probably not reading this anyway!

Recommended!

/ Nurgleprobe

reviewText:
I did not expect to like this game so much, a board game with CCG-style deck building and a little dice-based PVP. The game mechanics allow big late-game reversals of fortune, so a skilled or lucky opponent can often find a opportunity to come back from behind. Often ends in a race to the finish with other players ganging up on whoever's closest to victory so that they don't win first. Best played with human opponents though, because the game's AI opponents make many mistakes.

Also, game developer Orange Juice pays attention to its players and actively tweaks things in updates to improve game balance.

If you like CCGs and board games, give the demo a try.

reviewText: So...I bought this game, looked cute and that totally won me over...I was cruelly tempted by Eden's apple. I once believed Monopoly to be the most corrupt game on this planet. I was wrong. 100% Orange Juice is by far the more dangerous board game out there - it belongs in a totally different category. It is very engaging and lets say lady luck may either be by your side or sticking a knife in your back. Or in this case warping you to the other side of the map, far, far and even further way from sweet sweet home *sigh*. If you are into the trolls this game will supply the lols! Don't get me wrong. I LOVE this game, with plenty of hate on the side ~ But hey who does't love rolling the dice to only get a 1?...3 times in a row. Personally I'd prefer to roll a double 3 times and go to jail than be ultimately trolled but that would be too kind. This game will definitely prove to be addictive and entertaining for everyone, I deeply recommend playing it, because like I said above, playing with other people online, totally justifies the crushing experience. Best game in it's category and at a very nice price~ Spread the 100% Orange Juice, its part of your 5 a day~

reviewText:
100% Orange Juice is an Anime Style Objective-based board game by Developer Orange_Juice starring characters from other titles such as QP Shooting - Dangerous!!, SUGURI, and Acceleration of SUGURI X-Edition HD.

The game itself is far from perfect, but is quirky and fun and doesn't take itself to seriously. The gameplays starts off like most board games where it's 4 players pitted against each other. You start off by picking your character and after you have chosen you go to a deck buildig screen, yes I said it a deck building screen. This is what I think really sets this game apart and makes it wonderful. As you play you gather stars and using those stars you can buy boster packs and unlock more cards to play with. Each card has it's own properties and categories ranging from Traps to Battle cards to Event cards and each one can save you.

After you have chosen the deck you want to play with the game finally begins. The main purpose is to complete all the objectives before your opponents. You start off by having to deliver 10 stars to one of the home bases and from there you pick your next objective which is either defeat 2 enemies or collect 20 stars. From there the objectives are the same, defeat enemies or collect stars, but grow more difficult with each level.  About halfway through the game a boss will show up and depending on what level you are playing on determines which boss you fight. The boss is three times as strong as any of the other enemies you fight on the enemy tiles and twice as strong as any of the players so defeating it is gonna take a while and you will probably die.

There is a lot to do in this game if you get bored of playing others online you can play campaign mode. There are also tons of stuff to unlock which will keep you playing for many many hours. Oh! did I mention that the games RNG in the dice rolls is outrageous and will probably frustrate the hell out of you, but in a good way (if there is one). Overall this is a really good board game despite the Anime-ness of it and if you can get past that you will definitely get your moneys worth.

reviewText: Despite the fact that this game is almost all about luck and RNG, it is very hard for me to dislike this game. In fact, I really do like it! The characters are cute, the story is humorous and tongue in cheek, the gameplay is simple but fun, it's basically a standard tabletop board game with adorable anime characters. Even with the collectible card aspect I can definitely imagine this game being easily recreated in real life. I will admit that the final boss is likely cheating on her rolls, and the RNG will likely mess you up when you need it to help the most, but I've had a bizzare amount of luck with this game.\n\nWhat amounts to strategy" in this game is only choosing which cards to put in the deck

reviewText:
100% Orange Juice is 100% chance. Whether its by getting killed right after collecting enough stars to win, or stepping on a boss panel & dieing 5 times in a row, something will troll you.

These aspects will make for fun rounds with friends.

Sound asset seems to be kinda repetative, especially if you hit speed up [Shift + Ctrl], so I recommend lowering the voice & effect volume a lot.

Tip:
Unless your masochistic, don't play single player with the character marked as expert.
41 first casual campain matches lost [13 hours]. 42nd try I finally won. Not kidding. That mode seems to be weighting the dice rolls to make you lose, rather than just having a character thats hard to deal with.

reviewText: 100% Orange Juice is a game that when you look at it, seems very similar to Mario Party. In a sense, it is. You collect Stars and cards in order to help you progress through the game. You roll a dice and move around the board and land on a space that has various effects ranging from you to collecting stars or cards, to losing stars and fighting enemies. Now, that's where the similarities end really. 100% OJ is by far more rutheless than Mario Party. Maybe it's just my luck, but even on normal the cpus are brutal and out for blood. If you make one wrong move, or if the game decides it hates you then you can very well go from a blazing lead to being in dead last within the span of a few turns. Now, despite that, the game itself is a lot of fun. Sure, it's a board game with goals that range from collecting a certain amount of stars, knocking out a certain amount of people or a combination of the both.\n\nThe game has only 3 modes really, campaign, single matches and multiplayer. Now with any board game, playing with friends is what makes it really shine a bit more. You can play with up to three other friends, using whatever characters you unlocked, making a deck of x amount of cards and then you're put into a board, fighting or running for your life (depending on your play style and character as all characters have different stats.) in order to gain first prize. Now, with all three game modes you ear stars (which are this games currency to buy items from the store.) But only in multiplayer can you gain exp to level up and unlock new items to purchase and the sort, which the game has a decent amount of. Honestly, I suggest giving the demo a try to get a feel for the game, then convince some friends to get the game as well or find some people that would want to play. All in all, it's a fun game but can be frustrating.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you want to play this game, and you should, you better be a forgiving person.
RNG is going to ♥♥♥♥ you over so many times you'll never want to drink orange juice again due to the PTSD you'll have gotten from this game.
Soon all hope of ever achieving anything will evaporate from your life.
The game will play cheery music as you roll 2's every time you get KO'ed so you can't get revived.
The AI will use boost cards that get them to 10+ attack so you can't really do anything to survive.
Somehow they will always roll what they need in order to land on the home tile.
And if you do somehow win, just know that every level you progress in a campaign, the more the cute characters want you to fail.

This game is 20% skill, 10% luck and 70% RNG bias against you.

Rather, we should rename this game 100% RNG HATES PLAYER HAHAHAHA"


Anyways

reviewText: Alright so after playing this game for the 13 minutes I have, I can safely say I am qualified to write a review on the subject. Anything in this game can kill you. Other players? Yep. Robots? Yep. Birds? Well if you come into contact with a bird, it might be worthwhile to just alt+f4. You pick between 4 characters, Easy, Medium, Hard, Medium. They are just difficulty settings, but also they have different stats but only sometimes? On the game board it has 4 square types. Red=Random battle, Blue=Drop an ammount of stars, Green= Draw a card, And Purple=Random teleport. But if you land on the same square as another player, you battle. Imagine fire emblems battling, but without any skill. You roll a dice and hope to get higher than the enemy. Pray to RNGesus that just for once he will be on your side. How to win the game? I dunno the specific requirements, but from what I can tell, you get stars. Now sometimes these stars make your win" counter go up
date: but only sometimes I guess? This game is a whole jumble of nonsense wrapped up in a kwaii-desu bow. Coming off of the dark souls 2 DLC
recommended: I expected something lighthearted. Oh boy was I wrong. This has some of the most hardcore music I have ever heard. There is no reason not to buy this game. 10/10"

reviewText: This game is the epitome of rage... and I love it. It's a really fun game to pick up for half an hour every now and then (this quickly becomes one hour, then two and so on) and it is really addictive, too addictive perhaps. It's flaw however is that the game, at least in single player mode, cheats. It cheats like a motherclucker. Like a four year old playing monopoly. If you're planning on playing the campaign of this game, be ready to exhaust your vocabulary of swears. That aside, it's definitely the best board game simulator on Steam.
